hints.content: Parabolas that "open up" have a "cup" orientation, like $\cup$, and parabolas that "open down" have a "cap" orientation, like $\cap$.

These are the parabolas that open up:

![A parabola with a minimum point in quadrant 1 and no x-intercepts](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7aff637435513b5017ea4282b3762c74f3c1c19a)

![A parabola with a minimum point on the negative x-axis and a y-intercept on the positive y-axis](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cf04a00f07d32823fa7732c4279f05706ebdadb2)

choices.content: ![A parabola with a maximum point in quadrant 2 and 2 x-intercepts](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b9a1a5dbc2b45df4c648d3d0037b4b22f10036fb)
![A parabola with a minimum point in quadrant 1 and no x-intercepts](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7aff637435513b5017ea4282b3762c74f3c1c19a)
![A parabola with a minimum point on the negative x-axis and a y-intercept on the positive y-axis](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cf04a00f07d32823fa7732c4279f05706ebdadb2)

Our parabola's axis of symmetry is the line $x=-3$.

![A parabola opens down. It crosses the x-intercept at negative 5, 0 and at negative 1, 0. A vertical line representing the equation x equals negative 3 intersects with the parabola. ](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3c404de44f588d35012181abfae75edaaea3d72e)

question.content:
**Draw the parabola's axis of symmetry.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 2]]

hints.content:
ŤŢĥȟéè ṽṿéèŕřťțéèẍẋ óòḟ áà ṕṗáàŕřáàƀḃóòĺľáà íìśŝ ťțĥȟéè ĺľóòẃẁéèśŝťț óòŕř ĥȟíìĝǧĥȟéèśŝťț ṕṗóòíìńňťț óòḟ ťțĥȟéè ṕṗáàŕřáàƀḃóòĺľáà (ďđéèṕṗéèńňďđíìńňĝǧ óòńň ẃẁĥȟéèťțĥȟéèŕř ťțĥȟéè ṕṗáàŕřáàƀḃóòĺľáà óòṕṗéèńňśŝ úùṕṗ óòŕř ďđóòẃẁńň).

ŤŢĥȟéè ṽṿéèŕřťțéèẍẋ íìśŝ áàĺľśŝóò ťțĥȟéè ṕṗáàŕřáàƀḃóòĺľáà'śŝ íìńňťțéèŕřśŝéèćĉťțíìóòńň ẃẁíìťțĥȟ íìťțśŝ áàẍẋíìśŝ óòḟ śŝýḿṁḿṁéèťțŕřý.

The vertex of our parabola is at $(2,-4)$.

![A parabola opens up. It crosses the x-intercept at 0, 0 and at 4, 0. A point on the parabola at 2, negative 4 is labeled vertex.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8caae41ea03d59597f78e869bd6fc17645563894)

question.content:
**Mark the vertex of the parabola.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Let's review each option.

This parabola intersects the $x$-axis at two points.

![A parabola opens down and has a vertex in quadrant 2. Two point mark the intersections of the parabola with the x-axis.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/545162f1bf423c427eaa2d53d8326e7b60ef0887)

This parabola doesn't intersect the $x$-axis at all! (Yes, this can happen with parabolas.)

![A parabola opens up and has a vertex in quadrant 1.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7aff637435513b5017ea4282b3762c74f3c1c19a)

This parabola touches the $x$-axis with its vertex. Therefore, it has exactly one $x$-intercept.

![A parabola opens up and has a vertex on the negative x-axis. 1 point marks the intersection of the parabola with the x-axis.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a67f3e8cda40cc96da9308c343f02067366cbea5)

*Note that whenever a parabola has exactly one $x$-intercept, that intercept will be the vertex, and the parabola will be touching the $x$-axis instead of crossing it.*

choices.content: ![A parabola opens down and has a vertex in quadrant 2.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b9a1a5dbc2b45df4c648d3d0037b4b22f10036fb)
![A parabola opens up and has a vertex in quadrant 1.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7aff637435513b5017ea4282b3762c74f3c1c19a)
![A parabola opens up and has a vertex on the negative x-axis.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/cf04a00f07d32823fa7732c4279f05706ebdadb2)

hints.content:
We start with a vertex. This vertex is either the minimum or the maximum point of the parabola.

![A point at the coordinates 3, 5.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3bfe70ea6975665cac37c5b0386f0131c395b64b)

Since the $y$-intercept is *below* the vertex, we know the parabola *opens down*.

![A point at the coordinates 0, 1. Another point at the coordinates 3, 5 with a curved segment that opens down passing through it.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c415823794bd3b768939bf2344d4ff26bc5f4843)

question.content:
**Graph a parabola whose vertex is at $(3,5)$ with $y$-intercept at $y=1$.**

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
The first thing we have to do in order to graph the parabola is find its vertex.

We are given that the parabola's minimum value is $y=-4$, so we know the vertex's $y$-coordinate is $-4$.

We can find the vertex's $x$-coordinate by taking the average of the two $x$-intercepts:

$\dfrac{(-3)+(5)}{2}=1$

So the vertex is at $(1,-4)$.

In order to graph, we need one more point on the parabola. We can use one of the given $x$-intercepts, like $(-3,0)$.

[[☃ grapher 1]]

question.content:
**Graph a parabola whose $x$-intercepts are at $x=-3$ and $x=5$ and whose minimum value is $y=-4$.**

[[☃ grapher 1]]

hints.content:
Recall that the vertex is on the parabola's axis of symmetry.

How can this help us find the vertex's $x$-coordinate?

Since the vertex is on the axis of symmetry, it will be exactly between the two $x$-intercepts:

![A parabola crosses the x-axis at 2 points. A vertical line intersect the x-axis halfway between those 2 points and intersects the parabola at its vertex.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4e8e6e111f410f8d054ffef9b081f16e861e14cb)

So to find the vertex's $x$-coordinate, we can take the average of the two zeros:

$\dfrac{9+3}{2}=6$

question.content:
A parabola intersects the $x$-axis at $x=3$ and $x=9$.

**What is the $x$-coordinate of the parabola's vertex?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]]
